And this is when we found out. This was to wards the end. And she could tell them, one of the daughters is alive in Fairlong, New Jersey.

segments.question: I hear that people in Lodz before the ghetto was sealed...
segments.answer: Closed.

segments.question: Closed. They figured that it™s better to go to Warsaw because this is not going to be annexed to the Reich as opposed to Lodz which became part of the Reic h and so they were afraid...
segments.answer: Who knew that they would annex th e Lodz city...?

segments.question: Wasn™t it right away announced?
segments.answer: I™m sorry. I have to butt in because I lived through it. My father, when the Germans started to invade, to come into Lodz, my father and my brot her went to Warsaw because every patriotic Pole 31 went to defend the City of Warsaw. And my father came back must be a week later, his feet were bleeding and he looked, he wa s a shadow of a person, they tried to walk towards Warsaw. End of Tape 2. 32 Tape 3

data: Jumping to 1944, did you feel or know or consider yourself in some way privileged that you were in the last transport?
We were privileged. We were definitely privileged in the last transport.
You were only around 300 people?
Because they were already...
There were a few young doct ors, a few doctors and people that use to work close in the administration.

At that time we did not know that already are other people like Alan Yakovobitch (ph) knew that we would not be staying in Sachse nhausen. That we will be going somewhere else to work, in other words, it™s like slaves, like going into slave labor, okay? But we didn™t know that, only when we came to Sachsenhausen we were to ld we are not staying here. Afte r two weeks we went to Kern-eswoo-sen-hausen (ph) because the barracks were not ready. But in the mean time when we came in they were just about ready to be occupied. And then we got the straw mattresses and stuff like this.
Wasn™t Stefan V ee-ter (ph) with you?
Sure he was with me.
Was he working in his profession there or what?
He was a doctor, but...
This is the Dr. Vee-ter (ph) I told you lives in Tel Aviv. He was with him on the transport.
He was with us and there was another doctor with us and he wa s also on the circus saw and he lost...
Oh, I know who it wa s. Dr. Tennenbaum.

Tennenbaum. He lost three fing ers. He also was th e same as what I did with these big plywood plates on a circus saw. And he did the same thin g and he got his hand too close, the right hand, got to close to the circus saw and cut off three fingers. And he was a su rgeon! So afterwards he could not operate anymore because he had lost those three fingers on his right hand.

segments.question: Could you describe the co ntrast between what you expe cted while on the train, on the transport...?
segments.answer: Which transport?

data: To Sachsenhausen. And after your arrival and realizing what is going on?
Well, until we came to Sach senhausen we were together with our women in the cattle cars.
Cattle cars, strangers, I don™t know how many people in one, couldn™t sit down.
Everybody knows already how the transport took us in the cattle cars.
No, not everybod y, no. I don™t know how many people but I know we couldn™t sit down.
Wall to wall. Shoulder on shoulder.
I know they put with us a pail. You had to do something in front of everyb ody, you did it, strangers. Men and women.
It was a long trip.
How long?
I think it was a day and a night.
I think it was more like two days and we didn™t have windows to look out.
I think two days and one night, something like this. And then the train stopped. All men out!
I will never forget th is moment, this was the worst moment in my life.
I didn™t even say good-bye to her.
Here was my father...
My father, her father, her brother... 33
My brother! He left the train when they took them out of the train, he never looked back. He never said good-bye to me, he never looked. This picture...
I remember! I didn™t want to say good-bye because I didn™t want to break down. I had to be strong. I knew I had to be strong.
What did you know, what did you think, why...?
I had to be strong because...
We separated, that was all we knew.
This was the only possibility because we were separated. We were only married...
Few months.
No, we were married...
We married in ‚43 Be rt and this was ‚44.
Yes, we married in June and this was ‚44...
About a year later.

Yes, a little over a year. So we basically were still on our honeymoon. If you can call that, you know. First of all, I was frustr ated. Not knowing what happened ne xt, okay? And second of all, I didn™t want to see that I had tears in my eyes, I didn™t want her to se e that, so I just left out with the transport.
And this is when I saw the last time my father.
And we lost he r father because...
He was about 40 years, not even 40 years old.

And I was met at Alan Yakov obitch (ph) because he was the nu mbero uno on this transport. And one day, I was told to go outside, the outsid e commando, because they were always building tank traps because the H itler youth comes always with the ta nks over there were shooting against the Russian over our camp. One day, later on, I rea lized why he had sent me out. Because when I came back late that afternoon seventy people had left.
My brother and my father.

From our camp and amongst th em her father and her brother. They were amongst the seventy that were sent out and Alan Yakovobitch (ph) knew that if I would be in the camp I would never let them go because I would have told them that if they go, I go too.
But he liked you and he wouldn™t...

Well, he was like family beca use my sister was married, well , no, they were not married, but they went together, they were a pair. So, they were very close to each other. Aaro n was ever close to Dora anyhow.
So Bolic and Dora we re not actually married?
No, they were ma rried after the war.
They married in ‚45.
But he knew, Aaron knew, that I would never, ever have allo wed my father-in-law and brotherin-law to go.
Where did they go?

They went on a march to the North Sea to be put on a boat and bound out. It™s Final Solution. And he couldn™t walk anymore. So they shot him, all right? Was on May the 3rd, while my brother was able to escape.
They told my brothe r, too, run for his life , not to hang around. And my brother survived.
Since then, I was very, very mad. And as you say in Turkish, broy-gus-with-in (ph).
But we are in touch with his son, would you believe it? 34
His son called me. They lived in Brooklyn and he called me at that time to tell me that his father had passed away.
And he wanted us to go to the funeral.
And were we in Scranton or were we already in...
We were in Connecticut and th e next thing we left for Europe.
I had to leave for Europe so I told him, I™m sorry I cannot co me to the funeral. And every Christmas I get a post card...
Not a post card a regular letter!
Yeah, with their family printe d on it with a long letter of what had transpired during the year of what they had done and what they had accomplished and where they go.
So you felt that he is aski ng your forgiveness for sending yo ur father-in-law and brother-inlaw...?
He didn™t ask forgiveness, no.
No, this young man, it wasn™t his fault. He™s not responsible for his father.

segments.question: No, no, no. I am saying that you felt that Alan Yakovobitch...?
segments.answer: I absolutely, absolutely. He sent me out that day because he knew that I would never allow my father-in-law and brother-in-law to leave!

segments.question: How did Yakovobitch know that they are going to be sent on this march?
segments.answer: He must have known because he was in t ouch with the German camp, with the Germans.

segments.question: Had he worked with Bebof before?
segments.answer: Sure! On the __ ___________. Absolutely. Even very close, I must say.

data: Right. So he wo uld possibly know, people would tell him things?
Oh, sure, sure!

He would know because, as I mentioned to you, Zi-fed (ph) from the ghetto Fuf-eitel (ph), he was also with us in Kernet-woo-sure-hausen (ph), in that factory. As a German _____________. And they were very close and I was very close with Zi-fed (ph). He was a nice guy. But, he did not know that that was my fath er or my brother-in-law.

segments.question: He didn™t k now who it was?
segments.answer: No.

data: So he was simply trying to protect you?
But he didn™t have to protect me. Be cause I was working and I was, you know.
So was David and Dad.

Yes, but I mean, I was working in side the factory on a circus saw. And this day I was told to go away, okay? And then later on it happened that I got the rifle in my back, that I told you, on one of these outside commandos.

segments.question: Can you describe that during th is day and a night or maybe two days and a night on the train, what, and you were al l from Lodz, right?
segments.answer: Yes.

data: Was there any talk, any...?
It was frustration. You were so embarrassed, you know.
You tried to comfort each other for once. Saying to all, what will happen to us? Where will we go?
We had to accommodate ourselves because you have to get along in this place.
And you were actually occupied with yourself.
Did you think you were going to die>
We didn™t know what to think. 35
We didn™t know. The po ssibility existed everyday.
We were sure that...
The train was stopped by the, bo mbs were falling. So we could ha ve died right there. Not from the German end but from the Allied bombs. So, we didn™t know whether we would survive or not.
Yes, I mean in terms of this specific policy of the Germans at th is point. Here, everybody™s left the ghetto except these 800 people?
They told us were are going to be working.
But they told us we were going into...

segments.question: But did you still believe this was a real possibility?
segments.answer: No, no, we doubte d it. We didn™t know what to believe.

data: No body talked about the specifics?
No!
No, because nobody knew!

segments.question: When Teresa asked you whet her you felt privileged about being on the last transport, did you feel privileged in terms of your whole ghetto ex perience, given the position that you had in the ghetto?
segments.answer: That was one part. In another part, that I was Dora™s brother. This definitely was a privileged.

data: Did you get more food?
We got a little bit extra, yes.
When we were getting, I told you, the _______ of food, it was a small portion of meat, but Bert sent it to my parents. We never saw a thin g of it! My father looked like a skeleton.
And he was a tall man.
Over six feet tall, six-four.
Tall and, he needed it, definitely more than I did.

segments.question: Did they other heads of th e departments have a barber? They were all men, right?
segments.answer: I had my barber.

data: Yes, I know that. Did they all have a barber?
Everybody had this, th is fellow, this barber , he made the rounds.
He went, he went, he had quite...

segments.question: To all the heads of the department?
segments.answer: Pardon me?

segments.question: To all the heads of the departments?
segments.answer: To all, I wouldn™t say, but he had quite the amount of privileged people to go around and shave and cut their hair.

data: Was this in your life, prior to going to Lodz, was this a traditiona l male thing to do if you had a certain status to have somebody shave you?
You couldn™t shave yourself. You went to the barber to be shaved.
I went everyday to the barber.
When you were a kid? I mean, once you got a beard or when you grew up?
No, no. Before, I am talking about the general life without, I am not talking about the ghetto.
Everyone went to a barber.
I™m curious because it ™s not something one necessarily sees today.
Yeah. They couldn™t do it , cut their hair. They went to the barber ever yday to shave.
When father had this ___________ after we came back, we ha d a barber come here. Father and I to shave us. 36

segments.question: So this really had nothing to do with your positions in life, th is was what one would expect for the male population.
segments.answer: No, no, no. But he had this circle of people around him.

data: Did your sister have a hairdresser?
I don™t know.
I don™t even know.
I was wondering if the women had an equivalent?
You know, I couldn™t even answer th at question because I really don™t know.
I didn™t have a hairdresser, I can assure you! We didn™t take advantage...
Did you ever get your hair cut?
No. In ghetto , I had long hair.
You started off with short hair, like now.
Yeah.
But then you said before you le ft together you shaved your head?
I shaved. This is what happened. After we left the ghetto, I had the shor ter hair than you, very crew cut. This is why they didn™t actually...
I forgot to mention to you. I was honored by the SS in the camp. The little caps we wore, the cappies, right? And every time we passed a German...
You had to salute him!

We had to take our cappies off. And this gu y, he was one who was in charge of us, so called, okay? And he liked the way I salu ted him when I took off the cap. So he took me out, turned me around so I faced our people and he said, show them how to salu te! So I took my cap off, and he said, that™s the way you have to do it! And he allowe d me to let my hair grow.
No, he was bald like now.
My twenty-two and a half hair , I had, you couldn™t know if I ha d a haircut or not because there was nothing left. So he allowed me to have my hair cut, that was my reward.
To have your hair cut?
Not cut! Everybody ha d shaved their hair off.
In the camp. They didn™t want to ha ve the lice growing all over the place.
And I was allowed to le t my hair grow because I knew how to salute him.
Yeah, there were funny moments too.

segments.question: Did you have a lot of meetin g with your staff, these forty or fifty people who were...?
segments.answer: Almost every morning.

segments.question: All of them together?
segments.answer: No, not all of them.

segments.question: Parts of them?
segments.answer: The ones who are very important to me.

data: And who would that have been?
Bel-laf-sky (ph) was one. Then that girl from Ha mburg. The German girl.
Would you believe my governess was work ing for him? She wa s with us for the...
Sorry, Darling, I don™ t remember their names.

segments.question: And what would the meetings be like in the morning, what woul d you be discussing?
segments.answer: Whatever was, had to be done.

data: Like what?
Like a program. There were different occasi ons which I couldn™t tell you the details, no. But, there was always so mething which we had to do. They had to report to me. 37
There were so many factor ies, resorts they called them.
They had to give a report of what they did and how it was done and so on. There was always something going on.

segments.question: Did you have quotas for what people had to produce in each of these...?
segments.answer: No, no.

data: You didn™t. So when you would go to a factory a nd look around and talk to people and, if you would criticize something, what would you criticize if something was going wrong? What would be the kind of thing th at would be going wrong?
The cleanliness. The way, their condition s at the working places.
He would go to the kitchen and try the food. If they don™t cheat, the workers of the food.

I would go to the kitchen and look at the soup, which the worker s would receive, okay? Then I would make my comments, whether it was good or not good or whet her there is somebody and if I found somebody, he was fini shed with the kitchen.
You mean if they were stealing food?
They were stealing.
And we went to the factory, all right? And somebody from th e factory needing a little bit repair, would send in his place to the kitchen.

segments.question: Did I understand correctly that you were in the first period, one of the two people that were in charge of employment or labor?
segments.answer: Yeah.

data: And then you became the head of the labor?

segments.question: No, it was the other way around.
segments.answer: I was called and I was told to organize the de partment of labor because all people had to be registered to receive an ID card and without th e ID card, nobody would get the food coupons.

data: That was in the beginning or...?
That was when I came into the ghetto.
I have the papers still. Little pieces of paper when he was nominated to start the department. You want it? I have the original. It was lying in the little calendar.
I will copy it, I will only copy it.
That was November, ri ght, of ‚42, of ‚40?
Yes. That was 1940. And I interviewed a lot of people for the job, for the office.
I went with David to you, too, and I was staying in line with Dr. Kin-ee-roos (ph), he took me to you.
Well, in any case, to answ er your question, I wasn™t no minated to organize and run the department of labor, which I did.

segments.question: But there was another person, ri ght, that was like a co-director?
segments.answer: Later on. Not originally.

data: And then, in the beginn ing of ‚44 it changed again, that yo u were the only one in charge of...?
No, no, Shin-nit-skie (ph) was with me the whole time until the end and we got in 1943 from Czechoslovakia a transport was...
Andres was his name.
A 100% gentleman.
Professor Cas-par-ee (ph) was, this is a proverb.
I want to know about that, that™s later, tell me about the _____________.
He was a micro-biologist.
And he wanted the favo r of Rum-cof-sky (ph) and he was give n to my office to be the third man. 38

segments.question: His name was Anders?
segments.answer: No, it was Andres, A-N-D-R E-S. And he was with me also until the end.

segments.question: And how did you divide the duties?
segments.answer: With Andres I shared the office. Shin-nit-skie (ph) had his own office. But I put Andres in my office.

segments.question: Did you get along wi th Shin-nit-skie (ph)?
segments.answer: Yes, oh yes.

segments.question: Did you have to write reports directly to Rum-cof-ski (ph) or who did you report to?
segments.answer: Yes. To Rum-cof-ski (ph). Directly to him.

segments.question: And did he have comments?
segments.answer: Well, naturally, but in general he was satisfied with the way I handled it because in the beginning since it had to be organized we were three days and three nights, I got maybe two or three hours sleep, because I want to be with th e people. I have to wo rk sixteen and eighteen hours and then I let them go and I meet them, somebody else would work , so we registered day and night. Three days and three nights.

data: So people stood in line?
Yes, stood in line.
There were crowds of people.
To get their ken-car-ta (ph) or ous-vise (ph) or what?
Sure. It was like a ken-car-ta (ph) and this ken-car-ta (ph) they were getting their rations every week.

The ID they get later on from the archives, from Shun-dul-dom (ph), no, from Nef-tall-en (ph) who was in charge of it too, for ID cards. So he made out the ID cards afterw ards but the people had to be delegated to the various factories.

segments.question: And how did you make the decision about the, were the factories already set up?
segments.answer: No, they were in the process of setting up. And we had to select the people to go there.

data: And did you know how many pe ople could go into each factory or you made an approximate?
Well, they gave me a demand. I can take now twenty, I can take now fifty, I can take now a hundred, I can take now five. So, whatever the demand was.
He™s head of the workers or the factory...
They had to come to me an d tell me of what they wanted.
A paper assault, we can have a hundred people working there.

segments.question: But, three days and three nights that you were re gistering people, are you at the same time as you registering them designating them for a particular factory?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: So how long from the time that Rum-cof-ski (ph) hired you for this until you began to actually register people? A week? Two we eks? I mean, it had to take you some time to figure it out?
segments.answer: It took me about 10 da ys, if I remember right.

segments.question: To organize, to figu re out how to organize?
segments.answer: Yeah, to organize my office.

segments.question: And your talk ing about 1940?
And then, when people started there were demands for deportations and so me of the people were your workers from factories, right?
segments.answer: Yes. 39

data: And then people came and said, I hear there is a free space in the comb factory, or paper assault or...?
No.
There was no choice, they were assigned to where ever there was an opening and if they fit in, you had to know something.

You see, don™t forget that a lo t of people volunteered to go out of the ghetto. Forty-one, fortytwo, their still volunteers. And then came the demands. We want 1500 people, we want 1000 people, whatever. And then, where were the peop le? Everybody had to work so naturally we had given, like old people, I had made out maybe 500 or 600 papers to go to the straw resort, for instance. They were sitting there, there was nothing to do because there was that much work and that much places but people had, that they were delegated to the straw aut-tie-lum (ph) where we had old people, sick people. I must have made a few thousand people like this, you know. So, to answer your question, it took me ab out ten days to organize the staf f and I added as we went along and naturally after we were not through with the registries because, but three days and three nights it took to get the bulk into paperwork so they could get to the kitchen to get some food or get some, or where ever the food was distributed.

segments.question: So you registered ov er 100,000 people in th ree days and three night?
segments.answer: Yes. You cannot image what it was like.

data: I think I™m right. 1 20,000 at that time? In the beginning, in 1940?
Oh no, it was more.
When the ghetto was clos ed we had over 200,000.
Over 200,000, almost a quarter of a million people we had in the ghetto.
But then, very shortly the fi rst transport was organized. Wher e the rough element was sent out first. And then a lot of volunteers came to be out of the ghetto.

segments.question: Did they send a lot of very, very poor people?
segments.answer: By what do you mean, very p oor people? Everybody was poor!

segments.question: What I am wondering is , was their a hierarchy in the ghetto in terms of the population? Some people came in wealthy, right? Some people came in with things, other people came...
segments.answer: But they had to give everything away. There was a special place . Jewelry first...

data: But did everybody gi ve everything away?
No, no, you are absolutely right . Some people came in with some valuables. Then they started later on if they needed, and everybody was trading some valuables for food.
Bertie, we didn™t turn in our jewelry until the last day.

segments.question: But that™s what I mean.
segments.answer: That™s what I just said. That everybody who had something could bring it in because nobody, they didn™t have to undress, like when they went to the camp in Auschwitz, they had to completely strip and everything was taken aw ay from them. So, naturally, pe ople came into the ghetto with whatever valuables they had. But they did not hide.

segments.question: Right, but there would be some people who might not have had anything?
segments.answer: Absolutely. Most of them. Because let™s not forg et that there were a lot of poor Jews in Poland.

segments.question: Were they more vulnerable?
segments.answer: Vulnerable in what sense?

data: Well, vulnerable in terms of the amount of food they would get, their inability to barter or...?

No. They were better equipp ed to withstand these environments than the higher class of people because they were poor people. They were always in need for something so they could adjust to these bad circumstances and conditions much easier than like, people like my father-in-law who 40 was a very affluent man. He had everything he wa nted because he was a big owner of a big factory, okay? So naturally, he suffered much, much more and had much more trouble adjusting to these conditions than the guy who was poor.
When you see the pict ure from my wedding, he looked like a skeleton.
So also, on the survivor list, when you look at the survivors toda y, I would say th at about 80% of the surviving class were poor people.
Bert, be careful.

Today, if you talk to them, everybody was a big man with their factories and had a big working staff for themselves and everybody was rich and we know that they were eaten up by the lice. So you find that the element, or the class of people wh o were in that conditions before the war adjusted easier to the bad conditions in the ghetto than the better class of people, if we want to classify them.
Was that true for y ou? You didn™t come fr om a poor background.

For me I would say that sin ce I became right away in an upper position where I would get a little bit more than others I could easier adjust to the condition than most of them because as I said I was in terrific physical condition. Because I was a sportsman all the way through. I think that because of my physical condition I was able to survive and adjust to the conditions.

segments.question: In terms of your work, what wa s the hardest thing you had to do?
segments.answer: The hardest thing I had to do? That is a tough question.

segments.question: We talked about that yesterday.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: What was it at that time that made you say, I don™t want to be doing this anymore? Was there a specific incident or was it a set of incidents that happened to you?
segments.answer: No, the demands which were set forth to the ____ ____, to the department of labor, which I could not combine with any of my philo sophy and my characters. And wh en we actually were forced to support the committee who had to make lists of deportations, I just coul dn™t digest that. And that™s why, also with the influen ce of Irene, that I finagled myself ou t of that and let my other partner do this job. That was the time I would not, I would have loved to ge t out of it, out of the position I was in.

segments.question: And why do you thing, I know that Rum-cof-ski (ph) threaten ed you, but that was different. Why didn™t he say to you, you™ve got to do it? This is part of the job, you can™t do part of the job and not the other part of the job? Do you have any idea?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: Was there ever any talk between Rum-cof-sk i (ph) or just other heads of departments questioning or thinking about phi losophy and moral aspects of the work and the ch oosing and...?
segments.answer: I am sure such conditions, such c onferences and discu ssion took place.

data: Do you recall any sense of, more theoretical conversations?
Certain occasions, yes. We could discuss personal th ings and personal ideas.

When the Rabbi came, he was playing chess with the Rabbi. It was then that they had some discussions. Because Bert had a dilemma you know. There was a lot of nepotism going on, there was a lot of, like, my own cousi n. They came in, they wanted to bribe you and Bert would take them by the neck and throw them ou t. He was the heavy one. But he just couldn™t believe that you could put a price on a human life.

segments.question: So what did you talk about with the Rabbi when you played chess?
segments.answer: Various things of what his experiences because he had much more contac t with the people than I had. To him they came with al l their complaints and all their he adaches and conditions while they did not have, my door was not open to the general population be cause they had to go through 41 various instances before they coul d come to my office. You could not just walk into my office because otherwise I would have never been able to do anything.

segments.question: What extent did you feel as tools?
segments.answer: What?

segments.question: As tools, used by the Germans by how impossible your situation and position, yours and Rum-cof-ski (ph) and others?
segments.answer: Well, I must say thank heaven that I never had anything to deal with the Germans. My dealing was directly with Rum-cof-ski (ph).

segments.question: But in general, they built a certain structure in which the Jews in the ghetto had to do things that otherwise maybe they had to do, the Germans?
segments.answer: I couldn™t think of anything they asked us to do what they should do because they just...

segments.question: Well, like they assign people to factories and produce thing for them?
segments.answer: For themselves, for them personally?

data: No, not personal ly. For the good of the Reich?
Well, that was the purpose of our existence in the ghetto.
Of our survival.
We survived because of that.
